factoid: Count Rostóv is a marshal.
Count Rostóv has not sent half of his contingent to the front.
Count Rostóv came to town.
Count Rostóv wanted to invite Pierre to dinner.
Pierre gave Count Rostóv a pretty dinner.
Prince Andrew addressed his son and patted Pierre on the shoulder.
Prince Andrew said Pierre is a fine fellow and a friend.
Prince Andrew said Pierre stirs him up.
Prince Andrew said another person says clever things and one does not care to listen.
Prince Andrew said Pierre talks rubbish yet stirs an old fellow up.
Prince Andrew told Pierre to go and get along.
Prince Andrew said he might come and sit with Pierre at supper.
Prince Andrew said they would have another dispute.
Prince Andrew told Pierre to make friends with Princess Mary.
Prince Andrew shouted after Pierre through the door.
Pierre visited Bald Hills.
On his visit to Bald Hills, Pierre realized the strength and charm of his friendship with Prince Andrew.
The charm of Pierre's friendship with Prince Andrew was expressed in Prince Andrew's relations with his family and household.
Prince Andrew is a stern old prince.
Princess Mary is a gentle, timid princess.
Prince Andrew had scarcely known Pierre before.
Princess Mary had scarcely known Pierre before.
Pierre immediately felt like an old friend with Prince Andrew and Princess Mary.
Prince Andrew and Princess Mary were already fond of Pierre.
Princess Mary was won by Pierre's gentleness with the pilgrims.
Princess Mary gave Pierre her most radiant looks.
The one-year-old Prince Nicholas smiled at Pierre.
Prince Nicholas let himself be taken in Pierre's arms.
Michael Ivánovich looked at Pierre with a pleasant smile when Pierre talked to Prince Andrew.
Mademoiselle Bourienne looked at Pierre with a pleasant smile when Pierre talked to Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew came to supper.
The supper was on Pierre's account.
During the two days of Pierre's visit, Prince Andrew was extremely kind to Pierre.
Prince Andrew told Pierre to visit them again.
After Pierre left, the members of the household met together.
The members of the household began to express their opinions of Pierre.
People usually express opinions after a new acquaintance leaves.
In this case, no one said anything negative about Pierre.
Everyone said only good things about Pierre.
Rostóv returned from his leave.
Rostóv felt for the first time how close the bond was that united him to Denísov and the whole regiment.
Approaching the regiment, Rostóv felt as he had when approaching his home in Moscow.
When Rostóv saw the first hussar with the unbuttoned uniform of his regiment, he felt a sense of belonging.
When Rostóv recognized red-haired Deméntyev, he felt a sense of belonging.
When Rostóv saw the picket ropes of the roan horses, he felt a sense of belonging.
When Lavrúshka gleefully shouted to his master, 'The count has come!', Rostóv felt a sense of belonging.
Denísov, who had been asleep on his bed, ran disheveled out of the mud hut to embrace Rostóv.
The officers gathered around to greet Rostóv.
Rostóv experienced the same feeling as when his mother, father, and sister had embraced him.
Tears of joy choked Rostóv so that he could not speak.
The regiment was also a home.
The regiment was as unalterably dear and precious as Rostóv's parents' house.
Rostóv reported himself to the commander of the regiment.
Rostóv was reassigned to his former squadron.
Rostóv was on duty.
Rostóv went out foraging.
Rostóv entered into all the little interests of the regiment.
Rostóv felt deprived of liberty and bound in one narrow, unchanging frame.
Rostóv experienced the same sense of peace, moral support, and being at home as he had felt under his parents' roof.
In the regiment, there was no turmoil of the world at large.
In the regiment, he did not have to know his right place or take mistaken decisions.
In the regiment, there was no Sónya with whom he ought or ought not to have an explanation.
In the regiment, there was no possibility of going there or not going there.
In the regiment, there were not twenty-four hours in the day that could be spent in many ways.
In the regiment, there was not an innumerable crowd of people of whom none was nearer or farther from him.
In the regiment, there were no uncertain and undefined money relations with his father.
In the regiment, nothing recalled the terrible loss to Dólokhov.
In the regiment, all was clear and simple.
The whole world was divided into two unequal parts: the Pávlograd regiment and the rest.
The rest was no concern of Rostóv.
In the regiment, everything was definite: who was lieutenant, who was captain, who was a good fellow, who was a bad one, and who was a comrade.
The canteenkeeper gave one credit.
Rostóv's pay came every four months.
In the regiment, there was nothing to think out or decide.
In the regiment, one had to do nothing that was considered bad.
When given an order in the regiment, one had to do what was clearly, distinctly, and definitely ordered.
All would be well in the regiment.
Denísov is a commander of the regiment.
Prince Andrew had a son.
